posts.cooked:
(I‚Äôm not exactly talking about this, but it did inspire the idea)
In the interest of reducing the impact of spam / scam I think Signal should implement a WoT framework at the account level.
The TLDR is that better reputation = more trustworthy account

So lets say i have 5 people in my contact list who i know personally. They all have vouched for me by giving my account a +1. This would effectively give me a trust score of 5 and that could be publicly visible, it‚Äôs just a number, and there would be no way to know who gave me a +1.

I foresee this working with alongside marking a safety number as verified. Like if you know someone personally and you verify their safety number out of band, marking them verified should count as a +3.

Now lets say someone comes along and joins a public group, regardless of what their trust score is, if they begin sending spam messages, when people report report spam that could count as a -2. So reputation would be built slow, but can be destroyed fast if that account does something that most other users feel is worth banning them for. This will incentivize good behavior.

Now I know what you‚Äôre thinking, won‚Äôt the bad guys just get together and give themselves +1 to build up good reputation?
This is where the scoring will get slightly more complicated. If you have a trust score over a certain amount, lets say +100 and you‚Äôve had that score for at least a year, your reputation means more and thus reporting spam from that account should count for more, -10 for example. The score could even be restricted from growing too quickly, if the account is less than a week old and already has a score of +300 that could be indicative of an account getting created and building up reputation before beginning a spamming campaign, thus only the first few points would count and be visible. Some of the thresholds surrounding account age and score could include a degree of randomization. We wouldn‚Äôt want scammers just ‚Äúwatching the clock‚Äù so they know just when to strike.

Basically there are almost certainly more good people than bad, and they should be able to combine and scale their power to combat scammers; I think this could accomplish that goal.

So what do we think?

  • good idea, get the devs in here, lets do it
  • bad idea, what are you crazy?! this will never work
0 voters

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm not opposed to this, but do you see a lot of spam on Signal? The last spam message I got was multiple years ago, maybe as many as five, and now we can hide from discoverability, which further reduces spam. I think whatever Signal has done with their spam filter for the last 5 years is pretty sufficient without adding a Reddit-like ‚Äúkarma‚Äù system.

their spam isn‚Äôt really a filter, I think it‚Äôs just suspending an account from taking an action for x amount of time if there are y reports on that account.

That said yes it‚Äôs doing well, but scam accounts are still a problem.

posts.cooked: not many myself, but but there are claims of scammers at least a few times a month. I suspect they‚Äôre not targeting me because i‚Äôm an admin of the groups where they‚Äôre getting victim accounts. It‚Äôs difficult to tell good users from bad ones, unless the group members are as vigilant as I am.
i suspect they‚Äôre joining, gathering potential victim accounts, leaving the group, then scam campaign begins, then spin up a new account from a new number, and start over

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Weird. This shouldn‚Äôt be possible at any sort of scale if people are hiding their phone numbers. There‚Äôd be no identifier to use for bulk adds since usernames aren‚Äôt displayed anywhere except to the person they belong to.
but once you‚Äôre in a group you can message other users from that group directly, and add them to your own group; that‚Äôs typically what happens.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Yeah I guess the issue is that you‚Äôre trading profile keys and trusting other accounts by default when you join a group, which then makes you a contact in everyone else‚Äôs list. That‚Äôs a gap that needs to be fixed.

There should be a rate-limit or something like your proposed trust system for adding multiple users with similar groups to another group. However, I joined a new group where someone else was already a member that messaged me individually and I still had a message request to approve, which should also be true for new groups.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
You actually don‚Äôt have to interact with an account for it to be able to contact you even with discoverability off due to an unpublished exploit :)

Basically there‚Äôs a reason Group Send Endorsement is a thing. But it is mostly a public group chat issue.
How will you prevent people from destroying others‚Äô scores out of spite?

posts.name: Rico
posts.cooked: Bad idea, my Signal network is very small, so can I ever get a high score? And there are probably a lot more people like me.

Whatnoww:

You actually don‚Äôt have to interact with an account for it to be able to contact you even with discoverability off due to an unpublished exploit :)

Do you mean sending a message to a UUID?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: i‚Äôm just confused as to how it would work. it‚Äôll essentially require all people to broadcast all their contacts to all their other contacts, wouldn‚Äôt it? or are you intending for this to only be a thing in groups?

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a very good idea.

On one hand I have an account that has phone number visibility turned on and have only ever received two messages from people I didn‚Äôt know within it‚Äôs active time of about six years, one of which I‚Äôm pretty sure was just a wrong number.

Even if it were established, banning people because of it would be horrible for any group of people choosing not to participate.

I also absolutely agree with these concerns:

TeeJay82:

How will you prevent people from destroying others‚Äô scores out of spite?

Rico70:

Bad idea, my Signal network is very small, so can I ever get a high score?

I think it would have a sort of ‚Äúsocial media effect‚Äù where it basically ends up being a sort of ‚Äúfollower count‚Äù showing who is popular and whom people like better. It would also be a privacy issue, publicly displaying how many contacts a person has.

Another reason why it almost certainly won‚Äôt be implemented is this:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

CONTRIBUTING.md?plain=1

4b9cac43a 

      
    
          
  1. Thank you for supporting Signal and looking for ways to help. Please note that some conventions here might be a bit different than what you are used to, even if you have contributed to other open source projects before. Reading this document will help you save time and work effectively with the developers and other contributors.
    2. 
          
  2. 
          
  3. 
          
  4. ## Development Ideology
    5. 
          
  5. 
          
  6. Truths which we believe to be self-evident:
    7. 
          
  7. 
          
  8. 1. **The answer is not more options.**  If you feel compelled to add a preference that's exposed to the user, it's very possible you've made a wrong turn somewhere.
    9. 
          
  9. 1. **The user doesn't know what a key is.**  We need to minimize the points at which a user is exposed to this sort of terminology as extremely as possible.
    10. 
          
  10. 1. **There are no power users.**  The idea that some users "understand" concepts better than others has proven to be, for the most part, false. If anything, "power users" are more dangerous than the rest, and we should avoid exposing dangerous functionality to them.
    11. 
          
  11. 1. **If it's "like PGP," it's wrong.**  PGP is our guide for what not to do.
    12. 
          
  12. 1. **It's an asynchronous world.**  Be wary of anything that is anti-asynchronous: ACKs, protocol confirmations, or any protocol-level "advisory" message.
    13. 
          
  13. 1. **There is no such thing as time.**  Protocol ideas that require synchronized clocks are doomed to failure.
    14. 
          
  14. 
          
  15. 
          
  16. ## Building
    17. 
          
  17. 
          
  18. 1. Most things are pretty straightforward, and opening the project in Android Studio should get you most of the way there.
    19. 
          
  19. 1. Depending on your configuration, you'll also likely need to install additional SDK Tool components, namely the versions of NDK and CMake we are currently using in our [Docker](https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/main/reproducible-builds/Dockerfile#L30) configuration.
    20.

admittedly that‚Äôs an area that would need work
for people with a small network it probably won‚Äôt matter.
no giving someone a +1 would happen at the same level as sending them a message, and the total would be part of their profile. no need for any additional contact exchange.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
that sounds like a very bad idea to me. if it‚Äôs part of the profile, what‚Äôs preventing a custom client from changing that part of the profile, or discarding messages with a -1? the server certainly can‚Äôt intervene.
you‚Äôll need some type of signature attached to every claim, which would mean you‚Äôll need to know the key the claim comes from before you can trust it.
edit: and even then, that‚Äôll only prevent bad actors from modifying or adding claims, not from discarding ones they don‚Äôt want.
